title: Intentionality in Speech: Implications for Computational Models

author: Roger K. Moore, Department of Computer Science, University of Sheffield

segmentation: Thank you very much for all friend.
Good afternoon everybody.
Hello, good evening.
So I'm going to step a little bit back from the technology.

I'll come at it again as I get further on, but I I'm actually mostly what I want to do in this talk is remind you of what speech is, because this is the signal that we're interested in processing, and there are some rather important aspects of this amazing signal that tend to get overlooked.
So I really want to focus on that today.
But before I do that, I just want to add my congratulations to Alex.
This is we saw earlier this is this is a happy Alex read.

This was actually just recently in Adel wreck in Puerto Raj where I had the honor of following Alex as this year's winner of the Zampelli Prize and and it was there that Alex said, hey, do you know about this interact meeting?
Because I've not been involved in interact until this point, but soon as I saw the program, I thought, right?
This looks like a great place to be.
And thoroughly enjoying it so far.
So thank you for the invitation.
OK, so I want to really focus on, as I say, some aspect of speech which can be overlooked and that is intentionality.
We are dealing here with the signal which is or a signal which is not.
A simple coding system for communicating messages.
This is a behavior which is an emergent property of coupled living systems and that has a lot of rather important consequences, not least of which is that it is you typically done on purpose.
Now I'm not talking about sticking somebody in a recording room and getting them to read.
That is a very strange form of speech.
I'm talking about real speech.
In the real world, speech normally between one human being, another it is teleological.
It has a purpose, we it might not have an immediate practical purpose.
It might have a hidden social purpose, but it is there because different agents are trying to achieve something.
So we need to really understand what this means, what the implications of this are for the.
Behaviors which emerge, and subsequently, if we're interested in technology which we all hurt here, then how?
How does this impact on the kinds of computational models that we build, and thus far we've had a lot of good examples.
The computational models are very much treating speech as a static pattern, and all we have to do is develop the.
Mappings which allow us to relate that static pattern from one sort of representation acoustics, let's say to another representation which could be just lexical content.
What I want to sort of.
Show you here is that that really is a very superficial view of how speech is used in practice, and we have to accommodate that.
And in some way so.
The fact that we're communicating communicating intentions means that we wear.
Can view this as a as a system where optimization is taking place and we're trying to hit certain targets in our interactions.

We're trying to achieve effects in the world or in the mind of a listener when we are speaking, and it would be very common to think OK, I'm trying to achieve a perfect pronunciation when I'm speaking.
I'm trying to target the acoustics, but the evidence is not that we're optimizing at that level at all.
We are.
Optimizing the pragmatic we're optimizing our behaviors.
We're optimizing the cooperative or even competitive behaviors between individuals.
Which means then that then ripples down to these lower levels.
So what we think of as the most important property of the speech may be in fact emergent peripheral properties.
So what are the obstacles to successful interaction?
We have alternative interpretations.
Somebody can actually miss.
Understand what you're trying to do or what you're asking, and then we have competing external sources of interference which could be for something as simple as noise in the environment.
So just to give you an example of the consequences of this I've got.
Something here which is from Sarah Hawkins at Cambridge, which I think is a really good example.
She says she gives this example if talking to her husband at home for example, and she's lost the newspaper.
So she says to her husband.
So where's where's the newspaper?
Now he doesn't know where the newspaper is, and you might expect him to give a regular answer.
I don't know normal pronunciation, but notice that that's already somehow interesting.
Lee compressed.
He did not say I do not know.
However, if the for some strange reason there was a huge noise going on in the room.
the TV was blasting out loud, or some construction work right outside, then he might well say I do not know.
There might be other reasons that he might speak like that.
Um?
But if this is a familiar situation and they know each other very well, they know each other's voices.
The answer is more likely to be right at the bottom there, so those of you know your phonetics.
So when she's asked, where's the newspaper?
I know.
Now what did I say phonemic Lee?
That is a full form phonetic Lee.
We've got 3 little nasal sands.
The point is, there's a huge range there, that's a continuum.
It's not.
This is not discrete behavior, it's a continuum behavior which is under adaptive dynamic control.
As the interaction is going on.
And so this is a very significant source of potential variability.
And as we've heard, mopping up variability seems to be one of the challenges.
But rather than collecting huge amounts of data, maybe we should just recognize.
This is a dimension along which variability occurs, and consider how it might be modeled now.
What's regulating this?
Of course, this feedback.
The idea that behavior is simply generated with no attempt to determine whether the behavior is successful or not is a very old-fashioned idea.
Now we need to consider coupled systems where regulatory processes are in place.
We saw the example with the robot when when attempts to perform a behavior.
You wouldn't do that blind right all the time you're using feedback to determine whether the behavior is appropriate to what you're intending to achieve, and the same is true with speech.

We are all paying attention to our listeners when we are speaking and making dynamic small adjustments to everything from choosing the words right down to the micro phonetic details, and this is happening all the time.
It is variability.
But it is not random therefore.
Can be modeled So what evidence have we got out?
Not going to spend time on this except that you can see there's a long list here where we can see that such behavior is the norm.
This is how speech really is in in the wild for everything from parents talk talking to children to the famous Lombard effect into other compensations that people have.
Measured.
K So what can we do about this?
Well, we need to consider how this might be modeled in spoken language processing.
How can we cope with the fact that we have a variability here which is in some sense ordered and therefore model able and we can.
What I'm going to do now is show how we've gone about modeling that by using speech synthesis by by actually generating speech using some of the feedback mechanisms that I've.
Just described, so the general principles are in a some papers I wrote a couple of years ago which several of you are probably aware of.
The predictive sensory motor control and emulation.
It's an architecture.
The latest instantiation of that is.
I call it rather, not a very nice term, but MBD ACK which is a mutual beliefs, desires, intensions, actions and consequences architecture which you can see there.
I'm not going to describe that, but you can find details of that on my website, but what?
I want to do is go straight into the work of one of my PhD students where we've embedded some of these ideas in what we call reactive speech synthesis.
So this is a speech synthesizer which cares how well it's being understood and is going to dynamically adapt its behavior as a function of how well it thinks it's doing.
So if it thinks it's not doing very well, it's going to speak more clearly.
If it thinks everything is just fine, it's just going to hypo articulate.
So this is architecture.
See it's called C2H.
For reasons which I don't have time to go into, this is.
The generative feedforward path.
This is the feed.
That path, but what?
Want to do is get straight on and play a few examples to show the consequences.
So this is a hidden Markov model synthesis HTS.

The first example is we've got some big synthesizer speaking and a motor vehicle drives by Alice was beginning to get very tired of sitting by her sister on the bank and of having nothing to do once or twice she had peaked.
I was reading but it had no pictures or conversations in it.
And what is the use of a book thought Alice without pictures or conversation so you could hear the noise basically obscuring the speech as the that that was with no compensation whatsoever.
So now if we play it with the active dynamic listening speech synthesizer, this is what you get.
Alice was bigger.
Alice was beginning to get very tired of sitting by her sister on the bank and of having nothing to do once or twice she had peed.
Reading, but it had no pictures or conversations in it.
And what is the use of a book thought Alice right?
For some reason I think you heard the dynamic ones both times you didn't hear the one where it was obscured, right?
Sorry about that.
I don't know how the link, OK?
So we can look inside and see what's happening in.
This is in the valve space.
We analyze what the synthesizer is doing and so if we look at these two dimensions of hypo which is under articulation and Hyperx which is hyper articulating on the right and.
As the.
Rules are.
Did you conceive?
The vowels get.
Both are on the left and they get further apart on the right, just as as phonetic theory in this area predicts.
But this is all being generated automatically.
Similar consequence here on intelligibility.
So if we measure the intelligibility of the speech as we go from Hypho speech to.
Per speech so you can see that.
The distinctions are clearer in acoustically, and so we have this dimension under.
Active control, so hopefully here is just a couple more examples to finish off, so hopefully this will work.
So I'm going to play Hypo speech so this is under articulated.
I'll play the one which is under speech shaped noise at it's almost zero DB, so this is under articulated.
OK sorry bout that.
So now if I go to the hyper articulated end.
OK, so I'll just do that again.
So hopefully you can hear the much clearer voices punching through the noise, even though the signal to noise ratio is exactly the same.
My student Maro, as you probably could guess from his name is Italian, so he's repeated this in Italian.
It all works, so here's a hypo Italian in some car noise.
So he probably determined it was a female voice, which probably couldn't get anything about what she was saying.
Chest.
So hopefully the Italians in the audience will get the hyper version.
So that's really the story.
I just wanted to make a point that there are relationships that exist in speech signals which do not have to be simply mopped up with stochastic modeling.
There are deterministic relationships, we just need to understand what they are, and with appropriate models we can capture them.
And I just want to then finish with this.
This image, which is some graphic devices that I've developed and published recently to help understand some of the complexities.
Of interaction between living and nonliving systems.
And this particular these particular icons represent the human being on the left.
Interacting using language based interaction with a non living system on the right.
That's indicated by the box, but you notice that within each are representations of the other, and within that there are representations of the other.
Again, this is very significant.
Consequences of what we mean by by spoken language based interaction.
It is not just simple message passing, it's based on mutual understanding of a jewel of a coupled system.
But which aware each has knowledge of the other as priors.
And if we don't have those structures then we may not be able to enjoy speech based interaction with non living systems.
So that's why I wanted to finish.
Thanks very much for listening.
